Hotel Truntum Padang, formerly known as Hotel Inna Muara and once a colonial-era property, unfortunately falls short of the expectations associated with a 4-star rating. The room condition suggests a lack of proper maintenanceâ€”dirty walls with visible markings, old and stained bed sheets, outdated furniture, and misaligned lighting create an uninviting first impression. These are basic elements that should be addressed in any hotel, let alone one claiming premium status. The swimming pool itself is decent, but the surrounding area is poorly maintained, with broken and aged deckchairs diminishing the overall experience. Water pressure in the bathroom is reportedly weak, and the absence of a bidet highlights a lack of standard hygiene features. Air conditioning also underperformsâ€”guests have reported feeling warm even when the thermostat is set to 16Â°C, which suggests inefficiency in room climate control. On a brighter note, the hotelâ€™s historical value adds an interesting dimension. Paintings in the lobby narrate fragments of the buildingâ€™s past and Padangâ€™s colonial legacy, which could appeal to guests who appreciate heritage. The staff are also consistently praised for their friendliness, and the breakfast service stands out with its variety and quality, offering a genuinely pleasant start to the day. Despite its strategic location and historical charm, the overall guest experience is significantly affected by cleanliness issues, outdated facilities, and underwhelming maintenance. Without major improvements, it risks being remembered more for its nostalgic potential than for actual comfort. Many guests, while acknowledging its potential, have expressed hesitation to returnâ€”an unfortunate verdict for a property that once held prestige.

I stayed at the Truntum Hotel Padang a few months ago for two nights and I had a mixed experience. The hotel is located in a convenient location, close to the Padang Earthquake Monument, the Adityawarman Museum, and the Padang Beach. The hotel has a modern design and offers various facilities, such as a restaurant, a terrace, a fitness center, and a swimming pool. The staff were friendly and helpful, and the check-in and check-out process were smooth. However, I was disappointed by the quality of the Wi-Fi and the TV in my room. The Wi-Fi was painstakingly slow and often disconnected. I could barely browse the internet or stream a video. The TV was also kind of broken in some of the rooms. There's a broken line of pixels on my room's TV and a torn out screen in my sister's room. Overall, I think the Truntum Hotel Padang has a lot of potential, but it needs to improve its Wi-Fi and TV service. I hope they can address these problems soon and provide a better experience for their guests.

Huge building hotel, huge classy lobby, representative meeting hall, huge varieties of breakfast, good staff services. Room is spacious, but pity the amenities is bad : dark old towels, old bed sheets, dated room furniture.

The hotel used to be a Dutch colonial hotel and easily you can find the history of the hotel and few places in Padang from the paintings at the lobby. Initially the hotel should have earned 4 stars from the spacious room and delicious and variety of breakfast. However, we decided to downgrade to 3 stars due to the crucial factors listed below: 1) The cleanliness of the toilet is not up to the standard as a 4 star hotel (No bidet in the toilet). 2) The air-conditioning was poorly functioning (we feel the heat even though the temperature is set for 16 degree Celsius).

Hotel Truntum Padang, formerly known as Hotel Inna Muara and once a colonial-era property, unfortunately falls short of the expectations associated with a 4-star rating. The room condition suggests a lack of proper maintenanceâ€”dirty walls with visible markings, old and stained bed sheets, outdated furniture, and misaligned lighting create an uninviting first impression. These are basic elements that should be addressed in any hotel, let alone one claiming premium status. The swimming pool itself is decent, but the surrounding area is poorly maintained, with broken and aged deckchairs diminishing the overall experience. Water pressure in the bathroom is reportedly weak, and the absence of a bidet highlights a lack of standard hygiene features. Air conditioning also underperformsâ€”guests have reported feeling warm even when the thermostat is set to 16Â°C, which suggests inefficiency in room climate control. On a brighter note, the hotelâ€™s historical value adds an interesting dimension. Paintings in the lobby narrate fragments of the buildingâ€™s past and Padangâ€™s colonial legacy, which could appeal to guests who appreciate heritage. The staff are also consistently praised for their friendliness, and the breakfast service stands out with its variety and quality, offering a genuinely pleasant start to the day. Despite its strategic location and historical charm, the overall guest experience is significantly affected by cleanliness issues, outdated facilities, and underwhelming maintenance. Without major improvements, it risks being remembered more for its nostalgic potential than for actual comfort. Many guests, while acknowledging its potential, have expressed hesitation to returnâ€”an unfortunate verdict for a property that once held prestige.
